title: 109_s1018
content: The Act titled "Federal Employee Commuter Benefits Act of 2005" establishes transit pass transportation fringe benefits. The Federal Employee Commuter Benefits Act of 2005 requires covered agencies to offer transit pass transportation fringe benefits to qualified Federal employees in the National Capital Region starting the next fiscal year after enactment. The Federal Employee Commuter Benefits Act of 2005 mandates that covered agencies in the National Capital Region provide transit pass benefits to qualified Federal employees, with specific definitions and criteria outlined in the legislation. The Act requires covered agencies to terminate, postpone, or discontinue programs or benefits that do not meet specified requirements. Authority granted to use government vehicles for transporting federal employees to mass transit facilities. The amendment allows a passenger carrier to transport federal employees to mass transit facilities at the agency's cost. The amendment requires the use of alternative fuel vehicles for transportation services, aims to avoid additional gross income for tax purposes, and promotes coordination with other federal agencies to prevent duplication of services. Individuals receiving transportation services under this provision are not considered to be in the 'performance of duty'. The Administrator of General Services, in consultation with relevant bodies, is responsible for implementing these provisions. The amendment mandates the use of alternative fuel vehicles for transportation services and exempts them from certain regulations. It defines 'passenger carrier' and clarifies that transportation to a mass transit facility is considered official. Funding for maintenance and repair is also addressed. The authority to provide transportation services under section 1344(g) of title 31, United States Code, is in addition to any other available agency authority.
